user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskExit:
```c
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token) itself does not violate Rule 17.8. Passing the address of a local object is allowed because the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified. A violation would occur if the callee modifies the pointer parameter itself. For example, if the function has prototype void OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int, OS_object_token_t *token_ptr) and its body assigns to the parameter (e.g. token_ptr = NULL; or token_ptr = some_other_pointer;), that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Modifying *token_ptr (the object pointed to) would be permitted.
